question: It is so good of you to come. I feel that Rufus T. Firefly is the only logical successor to my dear departed husband. He has the statesmanship of Gladstone, the humility of Lincoln, and the wisdom of Pericles. As the widow of your last president, I have the right to choose -- and, Gentlemen, I refuse to discuss the matter any further.
answer: Mrs. Teasdale... my niece, Vera.

question: Your uncle has been such a friend to us in every crisis. Without his country's financial aid --
answer: What is money? Mrs. Teasdale, for you -- I would do anything.

question: Ambassador! I am so anxious for you to meet our new dictator.
answer: Mrs. Teasdale -- no matter who rules Freedonia, to me you will always be the first lady of the land.

question: As chairwoman of the reception committee, I welcome you and extend the good wishes of every man, woman and child of Freedonia. I deem it an honor on this momentous occasion...
answer: Never mind that stuff... Take a card.

question: What'll I do with this card?
answer: You can keep it -- I've got a whole pack... Now what were you saying?

question: As chairwoman of the reception committee, I welcome you with open arms.
answer: How late do you stay open?

question: In choosing you, I feel that I serve my country well. I heartily endorse everything you stand for.
answer: Well, I won't stand for much. And I won't stand for you if you don't show some improvement soon. Look at your report card last month -- "D" in spelling... six in behavior. Now who were the six? A fine state of affairs -- no wonder you can't matriculate, now what were you saying?

question: The future of Freedonia rests upon you. Promise me you will follow in my husband's footsteps.
answer: I haven't been on the job five minutes and already she's making advances to me. Not that I care -- but where is your husband?

question: Why - er -- my husband passed away... I was with him to the very end.
answer: No wonder he passed away. I'd like to be with you to the very end. Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you -- I love you.

question: Your Excellency!
answer: You're not so bad yourself, Mrs. Teasdale, when I look at you I can see that we're facing a crisis. We've got to balance the budget -- we've got to cut down everything including, you.

question: Thanks... but I can't stay very long.
answer: That's even a greater honor.

question: I bring you the greetings of my President and the good will of my people.
answer: I'll keep the greetings -- but you can send back the good will... what we need right now is twenty million dollars.

question: Twenty million dollars is a considerable sum... I'll have to discuss that with my Minister of Finance.
answer: Well, in the meantime, could you let me have $50 personally?

I'll tell you what I'll do. I'll give you Mrs. Teasdale as security. or my jackknife. If you want my advice, you'll take the jackknife... I've a better proposition... Make it $25 and I'll give you a first mortgage on my son and I hope you foreclose.

question: Your Excellency, haven't we met before?
answer: Why yes. I met you at the dog races -- say, you could have won that race if you tried a little harder.

question: Excellency, may I present my niece.
answer: Go ahead.

question: You don't understand. This is my niece Vera.
answer: And Vera niece, too.

question: You couldn't hang me in your bedroom -- I'll make a note of it. Where's my secretary?
answer: Here I am, Father.

question: Take a letter.
answer: Who to?

question: The President of the United States. My dear President... read it back...
answer: "My dear President"...

question: That doesn't sound right... take out "President"... now read it.
answer: "My dear"...

question: That's not right yet... put back "President" and take out "dear"... How does it read now?
answer: "My President"...

question: There's still something wrong with it... take out "President" ...now what've you got?
Now we're on the right track... Put back "dear"... How does it read?
answer: "My dear"...

question: You can't say that to the President... Put back "President"... Now let's hear how sounds.
answer: "My dear President"...

question: That's what I wanted in the first place. Tear it up and send it airmail.
answer: Is that all?

question: Take another letter... to my tailor. Dear Sir... enclosed find check for $100. Yours very truly... Send that immediately.
answer: I'll have to enclose the check first.

question: You do and I'll fire you.
answer: Your Excellency, the eyes of the world are upon you. Notables from every land are gathered here in your honor -- This is a gala day for us.

question: Well, a gal a day is enough for me. I couldn't handle any more.
answer: If it's not asking too much -- For our information just for illustration Tell us how you intend to run the nation.

question: These are the laws of my administration
answer: We're not allowed to tell a dirty joke HAIL, HAIL, FREEDONIA

question: If chewing gum is chewed, The chewer is pursued And in the hoosegow hidden...
answer: If we should choose to chew, we'll be pursued -

question: If any form of pleasure is exhibited Report to me and it will be prohibited. I'll put my foot down; So shall it be - This is the land of the free. The last man nearly ruined this place He didn't know what to do with it. If you think this country's bad off now Just wait 'till I get through with it. The treasury is low on dough; The last man went and flew with it. If you think we're short of money now Just wait 'till I get through with it. The country's taxes must be fixed - And I know what to do with it, If you think you're paying too much now, Just wait 'till I get through with it. If anyone gets fresh with me, I'll show him who's the boss; I'll stand upon my dignity, And toss him for a loss. And this will be the penalty For those who doublecross - We'll stand 'em up against the wall, and Pop goes the Weasel
answer: If you should make him cross, He'll toss you for a loss. If anyone gets fresh with him, He'll show him who's the boss.

question: I will not stand for anything that's crooked or unfair; I'm strictly on the up and up, So everyone beware. If anyone's caught taking graft And I don't get my share, we'll stand 'em up against the wall - and pop goes the weasel!
answer: So everyone beware Who's crooked or unfair; No one must take a bit of graft Unless he gets his share.

question: If any man should come between A husband and his bride, We find out which one she prefers By letting her decide. If she prefers the other man, The husband steps outside; We stand him up against the wall And Pop goes the Weasel!
answer: The husband steps outside; Relinquishes his bride; We stand him up against the wall And take him for a ride.

question: The population must increase With great rapidity. We give a couple seven years To raise a family. If, by that time, there is no branch Upon the family tree, we stand 'em up against the wall - and Pop goes the Weasel.
answer: You've made a wonderful impression. Your views are liberal... It is easy to see you have an open mind.

question: That's what I get for dressing in a hurry.
answer: Your Excellency, you mustn't forget your appointment at the House of Representatives... Have you got your speech ready?

question: I wrote a speech last night that'll knock them off their seats... Four score and seven years ago, our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation --
answer: Why, that's the speech that Lincoln made at Gettysburg...

question: He did?... I told my son not to leave it laying around... Where is son?
answer: Here I am, Father...

question: Send for my car...
answer: His Excellency's car!

question: I'm a man of one word... SCRAM!!! Go out and chase that peanut vendor away from the building -- Get rid of him if you have to use violence - if necessary call out the militia and if he isn't looking get me a bag of peanuts.
answer: I've tried to chase him but it's no use - he won't go -

question: He won't eh? - We'll see about that - send for your father immediately.
answer: But you're my father -

question: He's working very hard - I got him a job driving Firefly's car - He's-a driving him crazy and I'm driving him nuts - P-E-A-N-U-T-S
answer: I'll get rid of that pest - watch me -- Hey you!!

question: All right -
answer: Have you got a license?

question: No, but my dog he's a got millions of them --
answer: What kind of a dog is he?

question: He used to be a bloodhound but he's anemic --
answer: Well - what is he now?

question: He's half poodle and half watch dog -
answer: Half watch dog?

question: Yeh, he's only got one eye.
answer: I don't know much about dogs but you ought to be on the end of a leash - a ninety-nine year leash - Look - what do you call your dog?

question: I don't call him, I whistle.
answer: What do you whistle?

question: Yankee Poodle.
answer: I've got just the place for a man like you but I'm too busy right now to do any digging. What do you call your dog when you want him?

question: I don't want him.
answer: Well, if you don't want your dog why don't you put him in a pound?

question: He only weighs ten ounces --
answer: I can use you in the House of Representatives. We need a man who understands dogs -- and that's where this country is going to. Step inside. In case of fire, how long will it take to empty this place?

question: We'll start a fire -- -- and get rid of these microbes.
answer: Hello!... Yes... Yes... He's not in... That was for you.

question: I'm sorry I'm not in. I wanted to have a long talk with you... Now look here, my good man, you've got to stop yelling "peanuts" in front of the House of Representatives.
answer: Oh no, I can't do it.

question: You don't want to be a public nuisance, do you?
answer: Sure. How much does the job pay? Sure, if there's a chance for advancement.

question: You wouldn't consider going over Niagara Falls without a barrel?
answer: 'At's-a no good. I went to Niagara Falls once.

question: Did you shoot the rapids?
answer: No, but I shot some ducks.

question: If there was an open season for fellows like you, I'd get myself a hunting license. Anyway, I'm going to make you a sporting proposition. You give up the peanut stand and I'll make you vice-president of the country.
answer: Oh, no -- nothing doing. I had a brother who was a vice-president once and that's the last we ever heard of him.

question: Well, maybe he's still the vice- president. Now if I were to offer you --
answer: Hello... Yes... No, not yet... All right... Goodbye. That was for you again. He wants you to call him up as soon as you get back.

question: I don't know what's keeping me. I should've been here a long time ago. Now how about my proposition?
answer: What other job you got?

question: Let's see -- What've I got in my cabinet besides mice -- I've got it -- how would you like to be Secretary of the Interior?
answer: That's no good. I like to work on the outside. I must have something easy.

question: Then you don't wanna work hard?
answer: I don't wanna work at all.

question: In that case you'll have to take a civil service examination -- if you pass I'll put you in the post-office -- stick out your tongue.
answer: I don't wanna stick out my tongue.

question: Well, if you wanna work in the post- office you'll have to stick out your tongue.
answer: Look, I'm a very nervous man. I gotta have a job where I come to work at eleven -- go to lunch at twelve -- and quit at one. And twice a year I gotta have a six month vacation.

question: I've got just the job for you -- Secretary of War.
answer: 'At's-a fine.

question: You know, I'd be lost without a telephone. Now - where were we? Oh, yes - I just made you Secretary of War. The first thing you do is buy ammunition -- you buy it from me and I get 10% commission.
answer: What do I get?

question: You get half mine and I get half yours.
answer: I don't want to buy ammunition -- we no gotta war.

question: Then we've gotta start one. Do you know how to start a war?
answer: Sure, that's easy. You gotta insult somebody.

question: My card.
answer: That's a-no good. You gotta insult somebody from another country. Look -- I come from one country. You come from another country. I say something you don't like. You say something I don't like - and I'm insulted.

question: Why wasn't I insulted?
answer: You was insulted, but you don't know it.

question: Then I demand an apology!
answer: That's a-no good. If I apologize we no got a war. Look -- I send you a scrap of paper. You send me a scrap of paper -- and we have a scrap.

question: You've got a brain after all - and how you get along without it is amazing to me -- Now, who can I insult?... Who do we owe money to?... AMBASSADOR TRENTINO! How about him?
answer: He's-a very easy to insult -- I say something to his niece once, and he slapped my face.

question: Why didn't his niece slap your face?
answer: She did.

question: What did you say to her? You're lucky I don't slap your face -- you oughtta be ashamed of yourself. Where did you hear that story?
answer: You told it to me.

question: Oh, yes, I remember -- and I should have slapped Mrs. Teasdale's face when she told it to me... I'm going right out and find Trentino. You go right out and get yourself an army. Wait a minute. What kind of an army do you think we oughtta have?
answer: I think we oughtta have a standing army, so we can save money on chairs.

question: ...but would further cement the relations of our countries.
answer: Ambassador Trentino, I am indeed honored... But you see - well - I --

question: Oh. Then there his somebody else?
answer: Well no -- not exactly -- but --

question: What can this mug offer you? Wealth and family. I can't give you wealth... ...but we can have a little family of our own.
answer: Oh, Rufus!

question: All I can offer you is a Rufus over your head.
answer: Oh, Your Excellency, I don't know what to say.

question: I didn't come here to be insulted.
answer: That's what you think.

question: You swine!
answer: Give me that again!

question: You worm!
answer: Once more!

question: You upstart!
answer: That's it! No man lives who can call a Firefly an upstart. Touch.

question: Very well then, if that's how you feel about it -- My country has spoken.
answer: Then it's war?

question: Yes.
answer: How're ya fixed for ammunition?

question: Bah!!
answer: THEN IT'S WAR! THEN IT'S WAR! GATHER THE FORCES! HARNESS THE HORSES! THEN IT'S WAR!

question: You look pretty good to me - but very still need a spy - Have you got any credentials? You got credentials all right. This is fine. Put it back. I think I better take another look at that paper... I look this over later -- now I look you over. If you want to be a spy, you gotta be in good condition. I better examine you. There's something wrong -- I think I'm getting Whiteman's band. According to my watch it's four o'clock. Now look -- a woman spy is a-gotta make love to men. Come on -- let's see you make love... Now you feel my pulse. Send in the next girl.
answer: By the way, are you sure we need a spy?

question: Sure, we gotta have a spy. If we no got a spy who's gonna tell the other side what we're doing? Have you got any credentials?
answer: I don't go in much for modern art. Have you got anything by one of the old masters? I'm glad I didn't ask you for "Washington Crossing the Delaware".

question: We've gotta have somebody who knows how to get secrets from men. You know how to make love?
answer: You ought to carry a spare. We're certainly living in a marvelous age.

question: That's very funny... he certainly fooled me. He'll make a good spy.
answer: If we can't use him as a spy, we can have him framed.

question: Say, that's a nice collection. You oughta have a catalogue.
answer: Let's take a look at number eighteen.

question: Say, she's all right. You got-a her phone number? That's a funny one! I think we can use you. Here's a spy glass... go ahead and do some spying... He's going to make a good spy... that's not bad for the first day.
answer: That's not bad for any day. Maybe my eyes are bad - you take a look. You're right about that guy -- I think we've got something.

question: Perhaps... I'll call him... Hello, your Excellency?... I hate to disturb you -- I know you're a very busy man, but I must see you at once.
answer: Why not come over here? -- You can come in the back way and no one'll see you...

question: But your Excellency, you must -- oh thank you -- please hurry... He'll be right over...
answer: If I knew you were here I would've brought some cheese... So -- you've come to ask for clemency! I'll give the enemy no quarter -- not a dime...

question: But Your Excellency -- the Ambassador is here on a friendly visit... He came to ask you to patch up the breach.
answer: Let him patch up his own breeches...

question: Let him patch up his own breeches...
answer: I'm sorry we lost our tempers... I'm willing to forget if you are.

question: Forget? You ask me to forget... Why, my ancestors would rise from their graves... and I'd only have to bury them again... A Firefly never forgets...
answer: I am willing to apologize... I'm willing to do anything to prevent this war.

question: Well, maybe I am a little headstrong... But, you know, it's awfully hard to forget what he called me.
answer: What I called you... Why, what did I call you?

question: I don't remember.
answer: Oh -- you mean... worm?

question: No, that wasn't it...
answer: Was it -- swine?

question: No... it was a seven letter word.
answer: Oh yes! -- UPSTART!

question: That's it...
answer: Why - er - Mrs. Teasdale - this is an outrage! This man is impossible... My course is clear... this means war... You RUNT!

question: Yes, it's awful! Are you sure you did the right thing?
answer: Of course. Who ever heard of calling off a war after ordering all the ammunition? The plans of war are in this envelope. I want you to take care of them -- no one will ever suspect you. Guard them with your life... don't leave them out of your sight... If the enemy gets those papers we're lost. If they don't get them, we're lost. Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you? I love you... Mrs. Teasdale, you're the salt of the earth. They don't come any better than you...

question: Now -- er --
answer: Well -- they might come better but they don't come any bigger... and the bigger the better. The bigger the betta you've got on a horse, the more you lose, and speaking about horses, why don't you marry me. Come, come -- say yes and you'll never see me again. I'll go 'way if it means your happiness...

question: Oh, your Excellency, you take me off my feet.
answer: Swell chance I've got taking you off your feet... Gloria -- may I call you Gloria?

question: Why -- why -- of course.
answer: You can call me Gloria too. Gloria -- what a beautiful name. When I was born my mother named me Gloria -- two minutes later she found out her mistake...

question: You can call me Gloria too. Gloria -- what a beautiful name. When I was born my mother named me Gloria -- two minutes later she found out her mistake...
answer: Father...

question: Take a letter...
answer: Who to?

question: None of your business... Take another letter. Eureka Ammunition Company -- Gentlemen -- Your shipment of sailor hats arrived this morning by freight -- Gloria, I could go for you in a big way -- However, the rifles you sent were a little rusty -- -- and I don't say that to everybody -- Have not received last month's drawing account. How come? Your neck is like a swan... Yours very truly. Now read it back.
answer: Eureka Ammunition Company, Gentlemen. Your shipment of sailor hats arrived this morning by freight. Gloria, I could go for you in a big way. However, the rifles you sent were a little rusty and I don't say that to everybody. Have not received last month's drawing account; how come your neck is like a swan. Yours very truly...

question: They'll know I mean business then they get that letter... see that that gets out immediately and that goes for you too.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: I wonder what's keeping His Excellency?
answer: Never mind His Excellency -- you gotta your pocketbook?

question: Yes -- why?
answer: I wanna powder my nose...

question: If his Excellency doesn't get here soon, he'll miss the whole performance.
answer: He's-a not missing anything. He's in the dressing room with Vera Trentino.

question: In her dressing room? Why, what could he be doing there?
answer: He could be playing solitaire, but I don't think so.

question: What's the matter with you?
answer: What's the matter with you?

question: You haven't been still a moment since you've been here. You act as if you had neurosis --
answer: I no gotta new-rosis. My uncle he's- a got a flower shop -- he's-a gotta new-rosis.

question: Tired! I'd like to stretch this into a week -
answer: I hope I'm not interrupting.

question: Take a seat -- you're next.
answer: Your Excellency, something terrible has just happened.

question: That's all right. I'll fix you right up.
answer: My purse has been stolen -- the plans of war are in it.

question: WHAT ?
answer: I -- I may be wrong, but I suspect the Secretary of War.

question: Don't bother me - I'm thinking -- What was that?
answer: I said - I suspect the Secretary of War.

question: THIS IS TREASON!! What a fool I was to listen to your siren song and fall a helpless victim under the insidious spell of your irresistible charms --
answer: But -

question: You satisfied your selfish whims, while nations tottered, dynasties rocked and the world plunged headlong into a chasm of chaos and oblivion -- Not bad, eh?
answer: This is-a fine - you do a good job - you make-a no trouble and you waste- a no time. Come on, we take-a the plans to the Ambassador. You gotta the address?

question: Hands up!
answer: You no gotta no gun.

question: It's all your fault. Now we gotta steal the plans again -- You had 'em on you... you take a bath... and now we no gotta plans of war. You wait here -- I'll let you in.
answer: Psst... In the safe -- behind the drapes --

question: All right -- I'll meet you behind the drapes.
answer: No, no -- I mean the plans are in the safe.

question: Bad news -- its disastrous! Private Moscowitz quits! Clear all wires... The enemy has taken Hill 25, throwing twelve Hill-billies out of work... Our front is exposed to the enemy -- we'll have to bring up the rear... P.S. Have misplaced flag of truce... look in upper lefthand drawer of my bureau... Late again, eh? You haven't been on time once since this war started... Get out there and fight...
answer: I can't do it...

question: Why not? You're the Secretary of War, aren't you?
answer: Yes, but I'm not working for you any more. I'm on the other side.

question: Is that so? I used to think you were two-faced - but you can't be - or you wouldn't be wearing that one. Now - let's talk this thing over. Now -- how many men you got in your army?
answer: Well, we gotta one hundred thousand men.

question: That's not fair -- we've only got fifty thousand.
answer: That's all right. We let you have twenty-five thousand men -- and we both start even.

question: That's the spirit -- fifty-fifty.
answer: No. Seventy-five -- seventy-five.

question: Well, we'll let that one go. Now -- how many battalions you got?
answer: We gotta two battalions and one Frenchman.

question: I wish you were still working for me, so I could ask you to resign. How're ya fixed for cavalry?
answer: I've gotta five thousand men but no horses.

question: That's funny, we've got five thousand horses but no men.
answer: That's all right -- our men can ride your horses.

question: Not a bad idea. If our horses get tired they can ride your men for a change. Now, I don't mind letting you have our horses, but you must promise to put them through their maneuvers.
answer: Oh, sure. We have horse maneuvers every morning.

question: Acme Ammunition Company, eh? How do you expect to win the war with shells that don't go off? Now, if you were buying your stuff from me, you wouldn't have that trouble. Eureka Ammunition is guaranteed to explode -- or your money back. Let me show you some samples. Bring in No. 47, line 8. That's our latest number... our sixteen-inch Horowitz gun. Load it up. With a gun like that you can kill some of your own men.
answer: That's-a pretty good. I'll take a dozen of them.

question: Anything else?
answer: Yes, one gross of bullets, two dozen hand-grenades, three kegs of powder -- and throw in some matches.

question: Fine. We'll throw in the matches before we make the delivery. By the way, how're you fixed for spys?
answer: Fine. We gotta him.

question: So! -- He's on your side, too.
answer: Sure.

question: There's only one thing to do... we must capture Firefly. Ask for volunteers. Some one must make the sacrifice -- someone -- Here comes Chicolini. Maybe he'll do it. Unless we can make Firefly our prisoner, we're lost. Chicolini, you've come just in time. We need a man who's fearless, brave. A man who's willing to die, if necessary.
answer: All right -- I'll go out and find one.

question: Firefly must be captured at any cost.
answer: That's easy, I'll get him for you wholesale.

question: It must be done right away.
answer: I can't do it right away. I got a date with a General's wife. Not unless you find it out.

question: Gentlemen, the overhead is killing us. Everything is going up. If we don't watch ourselves, we'll come down with a crash. Now -- all those in favor of taking a cut say "aye"... Carried unanimously. Now go right out there and fight. You go out there and relieve General Beauregard, and while you're at it, see what General Motors is doing. Call him back -- he didn't salute me.
answer: Father, he didn't salute you either.

question: Attention! Go out there -- all of you -- and bring those generals back -- dead or alive. Why don't those generals come back?
answer: I'll call them.

question: Never mind, I'll go after them myself. Hey, Junior! Get my rifle. I'll get rid of them. Take a letter.
answer: To whom?

question: Hail, hail, Freedonia... Land of the brave and free!
answer: My dad is much too great for his position without a question. I'd like to offer this with your permission as a suggestion

question: We really think he should be king!
answer: I really think he should be king!

question: He should be king! And everything. He should be king!
answer: From what I have been gathering, I think they think I should be king

question: He should be king!
answer: And wear a crown and everything.

question: And everything. He should be king!
answer: You know I think they think I should be king. Although it would please me to govern the throng, suppose I were king and then everything went wrong.

question: The king can do no wrong! The king can do no wrong!
answer: Of course you're All aware a king must have an heir some one to pass the family name along will some one tell me where I'd ever get an heir if a king can do no wrong

question: The king can do no wrong!
answer: Suppose a pretty dame Into my castle came - And let us say that I was going strong. She might be stuck on me, but what good would it be, if the king can do no wrong.

question: The king can do to wrong!
answer: King Solomon was game he gave each Girl his name to number them would make a list that long I'll bet his thousand wives led miserable lives if the king can do no wrong.

question: We really think he should be king and wear a crown and everything.
answer: They think I should - They think I should - They think I should - They think I should be king.
